awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Retrieving the Late Pleistocene/Holocene Archaeology Record at the Carpenter Mining Quarry, Interior Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
Stratified archaeological sites in interior Alaska are critical to understanding the peopling of Beringia and the Americas. This rapid-response research involves the excavation and recovery of archaeological, geological, and paleoecological data from a multicomponent site in interior Alaska that is in imminent danger of destruction. Dating to the Late Pleistocene and early Holocene and located on a prominent landform, the site contains lithics and well-preserved organic materials from several time periods. The site’s location, stratification, and degree of preservation offer scientists unparalleled insights on ancient human adaptations to an ecosystem shifting from tundra to boreal forest.

Site XBD-00456 will be systematically excavated by arbitrary levels to document the cultural, environmental, and depositional history of the site. Lithic and bone artifacts, carbon and soil samples will be collected and analyzed according to professional archaeological standards. Geoarchaeological data will inform paleoecological reconstruction, while lithic artifacts will undergo XRF analysis to characterize their chemical composition. Recovered materials will be curated in Alaska and accessible for future study by researchers and descendant community members. Results will be disseminated via conference presentations, journal articles, and to descendant communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Alaska Museum of the North

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Alaska Museum of the North (UAMN) was awarded NSF Rapid Response Research (RAPID) program funding to excavate and recover archaeological, geological and paleoecological data from a regionally and nationally significant multi-component site, the Carpenter site, in interior Alaska, that was endanger of being destroyed by mining activities. These excavations provided an exceptional set of lithic and organic artifacts and spatial data on activity areas that date between 13,230 and 2,670 years ago. This research from the Carpenter site compliments on-going studies in the region that are helping to understand key events in the terminal Pleistocene and Holocene history of human adaptations to change from steppe/tundra to boreal forest environments, human colonization and population stability and dynamics in eastern Beringia (Alaska and Yukon), and long-term trends in Dene history.

The Carpenter site collections are housed at the UAMN, and through this grant, have been stabilized for long term curation and preservation and organized for its easy use in house use by researchers, and its catalog and associated data to be accessible online to researchers. Many archaeological sites in interior Alaska are being damaged or lost at an unprecedented rate due to industrial activities and natural erosional or climate driven exacerbated weathering. The long-term preservation and research accessibility at the UAMN support researchers in the development of research on subarctic and arctic societies and cultures and in Dene history.

The Carpenter site excavations recovered a series of stratified components in a thick loess (up to 2 m thick). Several blocks across Area 1 have 1 m or greater thick loess deposits and aide us in documenting the number of components, Cultural Zones (CZ), at the Carpenter site. A total of ~81 m2 area was excavated. We documented 15 cultural features (hearth and charcoal smears associated with faunal and artifact clusters) and collected over 2300 artifacts and over 8000 faunal remains, along with other samples (e.g., soil, charcoal, gastroliths [bird gizzard stones], and shell samples). Radiocarbon dates from organic materials associated with cultural materials established four distinct periods of occupation of the Carpenter site: CZ4: 13,230-12,660 cal BP; CZ3: 12,380-11,130 cal BP; CZ2: 10,310-9,330 cal BP; and CZ1: 7,130-2,760 cal BP.

The faunal remains were the most prevalent in the earliest occupations in CZ4 and CZ3. Cervids (elk and moose) were represented in both CZs’ faunal assemblages. Cervids including elk and moose were important staples to the economy to interior Alaska populations between 13,200 and 9,000 years ago. Moose is not always recognized in the early archaeological faunal assemblages and sometimes thought to be a more important resource later in the Holocene (after 6,000 years ago). But faunal assemblages such as the Carpenter site show moose had some importance to the diets of interior Alaska peoples as early 13,000 years ago. The small mammal record in the faunal assemblage recovered from the Carpenter site shows that small mammal use increased and diversified between from CZ4 (13,200-12,660 cal BP) and CZ3 (12,380-11,130 cal BP). Some non-food taxa include fox, wolf, and loon.

Stone artifact assemblages in the earliest cultural zones, CZ4 and CZ3, indicate tool maintenance and retooling events, rather than tool production, with some expedient (very quickly made) tools likely used for animal processing. Lithic assemblages from the later cultural zones, CZ2 and CZ1, have a wider variety of artifact types indicating a broad set of behaviors at the site during these periods including raw material testing, expedient tool production and use likely in relation to faunal processing, bifacial tool production, maintenance and retooling, and microblade production used as insets into bone and antler tools and in relation to composite tool maintenance. Several stone projectile points in the early occupations were excavated and associated with radiocarbon dates at the Carpenter site that will help researchers to refine the artifact typologies and cultural historical sequence in the region. 

Obsidian artifact sourcing analyses show the Batza Tena obsidian source, located in the Koyukuk River region, 400 miles northwest of Shaw Creek, was most widely obtained obsidian throughout CZ3, CZ2, and CZ1 occupations at the site. Batza Tena obsidian was likely acquired through trade given the long distance from the site.

We were able to employ graduate and undergraduate students between the 2021, 2022 and 2023 excavations and provide on the job field and laboratory training, and experience in collections management for museum cataloging and curation practices. Future analyses that will be performed related to the Carpenter site investigations will be a comparison with the collections from other sites along the Shaw Creek Bluff, including Broken Mammoth and Mead sites. Carpenter collections were accessioned to the University of Alaska Museum of the North by year of collection: UA2021-136, UA2022-119, UA2023-106, and UA2024-097.

 


Last Modified: 03/12/2025
Modified by: Joshua D Reuther
